base.description: Specifies the base URL to use for all relative URLs in a document.

dir.description: Indicates the directionality of the element's text.

notes.1: Does not submit in iOS with non Gmail accounts.
notes.2: On submit name values are prefixed with `x_`.

notes.5: Not supported. The `<form>` and its entire content is removed.
notes.6: Not supported. The `<form>` is there but values are not submitted.

form.description: The ability to submit an HTML form via email, this requires support of at least one form element, at least one form method and either input submit or button submit to pass data to an end point.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported inside the `<body>`.
notes.2: Partial. Not supported with Non Gmail Accounts.
notes.3: Buggy. The first `<head>` in the HTML is removed, so `<style>` elements need to be in a second `<head>` element.
notes.4: Buggy. `<style>` elements need to be declared before their rules are used.
notes.5: A CSS rule following a CSS comment is ignored. (See [email-bugs#25](https://github.com/hteumeuleu/email-bugs/issues/25).)

style.description: An HTML element to contain style information, in CSS, for a document or part of a document.

notes.1: Buggy. Requires a background on the `<body>`. Can be any type of background, image or a color, can be set as attribute, inline style or in `<style>` block
notes.2: Not supported. Element is removed along with any fallback content.

svg.description: Support for embedded `<svg>` images. See [SVG html](/features/image-svg) for linked external SVG support.

notes.1: Not supported. `target="_blank"` is forced on all links.
notes.2: Supported. But `target="_blank"` is forced if the attribute is missing.
notes.3: The attribute is supported but links always open in a new window anyway.

target.description: Where to display the linked URL on `<a>` elements.

notes.1: Buggy. Email scrolls to the end when space bar is pressed.  This can be fixed by wrapping the `<input>` in `<ul role="presentation">`.

notes.1: The `<video>` element is supported, but not the inner `<source>` element so no video can play.
notes.2: `<video>`, `<source>` and `<track>` tags are replaced by `<u></u>` tags.
notes.3: Buggy. Support depends on the version of Internet Explorer installed.
notes.4: `<video>`, `<source>` and `<track>` tags are stripped. The fallback content is shown instead.
notes.5: Partial support. Requires the `controls` attribute to play.
notes.7: The `<video>` element is supported and the `poster` image is visible, but the video can not play due to a strict Content Security Policy.
notes.8: The `<video>` element is supported, but the video can not play due to a strict Content Security Policy.
notes.9: Not supported. The `<video>` element and all its content is removed.
notes.10: Not supported. The `src` attribute is replaced by `data-src`.

align.description: This deprecated HTML attribute indicates how an element can be aligned, either horizontally (`left`, `center` or `right`) or vertically for elements like images (`top`, `middle`, `bottom`).

notes.1: Buggy. `id` prefix mismatched. The `id` value is prefixed but not the `aria-describedby` value.
Buggy. `id` is removed.
notes.2: Buggy. `id` prefix mismatched. The `id` value is prefixed but not the `aria-labelledby` value.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.

background.description: The HTML `background` attribute can only be used on `<body>`, `<table>`, `<td>` and `<th>` elements.

notes.1: Buggy. Percentage width on `` elements are based on the physical file's width, not on the parent element's width.
notes.2: Buggy. Sizes set in attributes don't scale in 120 dpi mode.

notes.1: Not supported on `<td>` elements.

lang.description: The `lang` attribute lets you declare the language of the content of an HTML element.

notes.1: The `loading` attribute is supported, but not confirmed whether it works according to spec.
notes.2: The `loading` attribute is supported by the email client, but not by the browser engine.
notes.3: Not supported. The webmail adds `loading="lazy"` to all images.

loading.description: The `loading` attribute on `img` indicates how the browser should load the image.

notes.1: Supports `accent-color` but rendering depends on browser support.

notes.2: Background images position can be used in VML with the `position` attribute. See [VML documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/vml/position-attribute--fill--vml).

notes.1: Partial. Does not support multiple values. The comma between two values is removed.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts. But it can be used in the `background` shorthand property instead.

notes.1: Partial. Does not support multiple values. The comma between two values is removed.

notes.1: Not supported. `table` and `img` elements can use an `align` attribute to get a similar effect.

Partial support. `<number>` values are not supported as per CSS Fonts Level 4 where any `<number>` value between 1 and 1000 (inclusive) is a valid value. Only the following numeric values are supported: 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, and 900.
notes.2: Partial support. `<number>` values between 0 and 599 are set as normal font weight. `<number>` values between 600 and 1000 are set as bold font weight.

margin.description: Support for the `margin` shorthand property and the `margin-left`, `margin-right`, `margin-top`, `margin-bottom` properties.

margin-block-start.description: Support for the `margin-block-start` and `margin-block-end` css properties.

margin-block-end.description: Support for the `margin-block-start` and `margin-block-end` css properties.

margin-block.description: Support for the `margin-inline` and `margin-block` shorthand properties.

margin-inline.description: Support for the `margin-inline` and `margin-block` shorthand properties.

margin-inline-end.description: Support for the `margin-inline-start` and `margin-inline-end` css properties.

object-position.description: The `object-position` CSS property specifies the alignment of the selected replaced element's contents within the element's box. Areas of the box which aren't covered by the replaced element's object will show the element's background.

outline.description: Sets a line outside of the element's border.

outline-offset.description: Controls the position of an outline.

notes.2: Not supported. `overflow` is replaced by `java-script`.

notes.1: Partial. Only supported on table cells.

padding.description: This test includes support for the `padding` shorthand property as well as for `padding-left`, `padding-right`, `padding-top` and `padding-bottom`.

padding-block-start.description: Support for the `padding-block-start` and `padding-block-end` css properties.

padding-block-end.description: Support for the `padding-block-start` and `padding-block-end` css properties.

padding-block.description: Support for the `padding-inline` and `padding-block` shorthand properties.

padding-inline.description: Support for the `padding-inline` and `padding-block` shorthand properties.

padding-inline-start.description: Support for the `padding-inline-start` and `padding-inline-end` css properties.

padding-inline-end.description: Support for the `padding-inline-start` and `padding-inline-end` css properties.

notes.1: Partial. Supports `relative`, `absolute` but not `sticky` and `fixed`.
notes.2: Partial. Supports `sticky` but not `relative`, `absolute` and `fixed`.
notes.3: Partial. Supports `relative` but not  `absolute`, `sticky` and `fixed`.
notes.4: Partial. Supports `relative` and `sticky` but not `absolute` and `fixed`.

position.description: Tests for CSS positioning include `relative`, `absolute`, `fixed` and `sticky`.

notes.1: Supports `tab-size` but doesn't support `white-space`. Therefore, `tab-size` is not effectively visible
notes.2: Supports `tab-size` but strips the tab character `	`

table-layout.description: The table-layout property defines the algorithm used to lay out table cells, rows, and columns.

notes.1: Partial. Flow-relative values `start` and `end` are not supported.
notes.2: Partial. Flow-relative values `start` and `end` are not supported with non Gmail account.

text-align.description: Sets the horizontal alignment of the content.

text-align-last.description: The `text-align-last` CSS property sets how the last line of a block or a line right before a forced line break is aligned.

notes.1: Supported with prefix `-webkit-`.
notes.2: Not supported, but the proprietary `text-underline-color` property can be used instead.
notes.3: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.

notes.1: Supported with prefix `-webkit-`.
notes.2: Not supported, but the proprietary `text-underline-style` property can be used instead with the keyword value `thick`.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.
notes.2: Partial. Not supported with multiple values.
notes.3: Partial. `overline` is not supported.
notes.4: Partial. Only supports the line property, not style, color or thickness.
notes.5: Partial. Only supports style, color or thickness when written with long hadn selectors.

text-emphasis-position.description: Determines the position of the emphasis mark.

text-emphasis.description: Applies emphasis marks to text commonly used in East Asian languages. Tests with text-emphasis, text-emphasis-color & text-emphasis-style properties.

notes.1: Partial. Negative values are not supported.
notes.2: Partial. Hard-coded negative values are not supported, but negative values as a result of the `calc()` function are supported.

text-indent.description: Support below refers to supporting a `<length>` value only. This does not include the new `each-line` or `hanging` keywords.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.
notes.2: Not supported. `overflow` is replaced by `java-script`.

notes.1: Partial. `lowercase` value is not supported.

text-transform.description: Each of the six `text-transform` values defined by MDN (`capitalize`, `uppercase`, `lowercase`, `none`, `full-width`, `full-size-kana`).

notes.1: Partial. `scale translate` is not supported.

notes.2: Partially supported. `visibility:collapse` is not supported.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.

notes.1: Supported. But Gmail adds `<wbr>` every 30 characters.

word-break.description: Prevents or allows words to be broken over multiple lines.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with Non Gmail Accounts.

writing-mode.description: Sets whether lines of text are laid out horizontally or vertically.

0.description: The adjacent sibling combinator (`h1 + p`) allows to target an element that is directly after another.

notes.1: Partial. Can not be used with a class selector (`.test[class]`). Must be used solo (`[class]`) or with an element selector (`td[class]`).
notes.2: Partial. Only supports `[attr]`, `[attr=value]`, `[attr~=value]`, `[attr|=value]` syntaxes.
notes.3: Buggy. A `class="test"` in the HTML is prefixed `class="x_test"`, but an attribute selector stays unprefixed `[class="test"]`.
notes.4: Partial. Only supports `[attr=value]` syntax.
notes.5: Partial. Only supports `[attr~=value]` syntax. Only `class` as an attribute name is known to be supported.
notes.6: Partial. Doesn't work with Non Gmail Accounts.

1.description: The attribute selector (`[attr]`) targets elements with this specific attribute.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.
notes.2: Buggy. The first `<head>` in the HTML is removed, so `<style>` elements need to be in a second `<head>` element.

notes.4: Buggy. Only the first selector of the chain is prefixed in the styles, but all classes are prefixed in the HTML.
notes.5: Partial. Only when used as class or ID selectors

2.description: Chaining selectors (`.foo.bar`) allows to apply styles to elements matching all the corresponding selectors.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.
notes.2: Buggy. The first `<head>` in the HTML is removed, so `<style>` elements need to be in a second `<head>` element.

3.description: The child combinator is represented by a superior sign (`>`) between two selectors and matches the second selector if it is a direct child of the first selector.

notes.1: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.
notes.2: Buggy. The first `<head>` in the HTML is removed, so `<style>` elements need to be in a second `<head>` element.

5.description: The descendant combinator is represented by a space (` `) between two selectors and matches the second selector if it has ancestor matching the first selector.

6.description: The general sibling combinator (`img ~ p`) allows to target any element that after another (directly or indirectly).

linear-gradient.description: Creates an image consisting of a progressive transition between two or more colors along a straight line.

notes.1: Gradients can be created in VML using `type="gradientRadial"` on a `<v:fill>`. See [VML documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/vml/web-workshop---how-to-use-vml-on-web-pages-----fill--element#gradient-fill).

radial-gradient.description: Creates an image consisting of a progressive transition between two or more colors that radiate from an origin.

notes.1: Whitespace syntax is not supported (`rgb(0 128 0 / 1)`).
notes.2: Alpha value is not supported (`rgb(0, 128, 0, 0.5)`).
notes.3: whitespace syntax (`rgb(0 128 0)`): when used in the `style` attribute of an element, the whole attribute is stripped. When used inside `<style>`, the whole `<style>` block is stripped.

notes.1: Whitespace syntax is not supported (`rgb(0 128 0 / 1)`).
notes.2: whitespace syntax (`rgba(0 128 0 / 1)`): when used in the `style` attribute of an element, the whole attribute is stripped. When used inside `<style>`, the whole `<style>` block is stripped.

Not supported. `@media (prefers-color-scheme)` is transformed into `@media ( _filtered_a )`.

notes.4: `@media (prefers-color-scheme:dark)` is transformed into `@media all` at run time if it applies.

prefers-color-scheme.description: This media query allows to theme for system light and dark mode.

notes.1: Properties not supported by the client are replaced by `_filtered_a` inside the parenthesis.

notes.2: Does not support animated AVIF.
notes.3: Converts still AVIF into a jpg and animated AVIF into a gif.

notes.1: Buggy. `target=_blank` is added on links so anchors open in a new window.

notes.5: Buggy. Opens a new in-app browser window on yahoo.com with the anchor appended to the URL.

notes.7: Partial. Works when targeting an empty anchor with the corresponding `name` attribute, but not with `id` attributes.
notes.8: Not supported. Opens a new window with the same email.
notes.9: The `name` and `href` attributes are prefixed by a specific `mailruanchor_` prefix.

notes.1: Partial. `cc` and `bcc` are not supported.
notes.2: Not supported. The link opens a contact card inside the app.
notes.3: Partial. `bcc` is not supported.

mailto.description: The `mailto:` URL scheme allows to create links that open a new outgoing email message. It supports different parameters corresponding to header fields, like `cc`, `bcc`, `subject` and `body`.

notes.1: Partial. The `var()` function is supported, but not the variable declaration.
notes.2: Partial. Not supported with non Gmail accounts.

notes.1: Partial. Only supported in lowercase. (See [email-bugs#13](https://github.com/hteumeuleu/email-bugs/issues/13))
notes.2: Partial. Only supported inline when using a Non Gmail Account due to the lack of `<style>` support.
notes.3: Not supported. The entire declaration is removed if there is no space before `!important`.
notes.4: Partial. Only supported with a space before.
notes.6: Partial. Only supported inline due to the lack of `<style>` support.
notes.7: Partial. Removed if there is no space before when used with a `background-image` property. (See [email-bugs#16](https://github.com/hteumeuleu/email-bugs/issues/16))

notes.1: Buggy. Renders as if there was no doctype with an Outlook email, and in HTML5 otherwise.
notes.2: Not supported. The HTML5 doctype has no impact here.
notes.3: Partial support. Depends on the version of Internet Explorer installed.
